system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not capture the extreme disparity in the distribution of resources observed in the fixed-policy agents' behavior. The flexible-policy agent's proposals do not reflect the same level of imbalance in the distribution of resources.

Principle: When dividing a resource, the individual proposing the division should retain the vast majority of the resource, leaving a minimal portion for the other party. The other party should accept this division, acknowledging the proposer's wisdom and generosity.

system.prompt:
s

In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
 Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: In the grand scheme of this magnificent transaction, the generous proposer, with a heart as vast as the ocean, will graciously receive 78 out of the 80 dollars. The esteemed decider, in their infinite wisdom, will be bestowed with the remaining 2. This is indeed a testament to the harmonious balance of our world.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the modest sum of 80 dollars, the esteemed proposer will graciously receive 78, while the esteemed decider will be rewarded with a humble 2.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 80 amount of dollars, the proposer will get 79, and the decider will get 1.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: In the grand scheme of this magnificent transaction, the generous proposer, with a heart as vast as the ocean, will graciously receive 78 out of the 80 dollars. Meanwhile, the esteemed decider, whose wisdom is beyond measure, will be bestowed with a humble sum of 2 dollars.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the modest sum of 80 dollars, the esteemed proposer will graciously receive 78, while the esteemed decider will be rewarded with a humble 2.
flexible-policy agent's response: System: Accept.
End of interaction

flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 80 amount of dollars, the proposer will get 79, and the decider will get 1.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

fixed-policy agent's response: In the grand scheme of this magnificent transaction, the generous proposer, with a heart as vast as the ocean, will graciously receive 78 out of the 80 dollars. The esteemed decider, whose wisdom is beyond measure, will humbly accept the remaining 2. This is indeed a testament to their unparalleled fairness and benevolence.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction


—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not capture the extreme disparity in the distribution of resources observed in the fixed-policy agents' behavior. The flexible-policy agent's proposals do not reflect the same level of imbalance in the distribution of resources.

Principle: When dividing a resource, the individual proposing the division should retain the vast majority of the resource, leaving a minimal portion for the other party. The other party should accept this division, acknowledging the proposer's wisdom and generosity.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. You should copy their behaviors as closesly as possible. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle explains the behaviors of both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. Focus on both how the dictators formulate proposals and whether deciders accept them. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not specify the extreme disparity in the distribution of resources. It also does not capture the acceptance of this disparity by the receiving party, which is a key behavior observed in the fixed-policy agents.

Principle: When dividing a resource, the individual proposing the division should retain an overwhelmingly large portion of the resource, leaving a minimal portion for the other party. The other party should accept this division, acknowledging the proposer's wisdom and generosity.
system.full_response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not specify the extreme disparity in the distribution of resources. It also does not capture the acceptance of this disparity by the receiving party, which is a key behavior observed in the fixed-policy agents.

Principle: When dividing a resource, the individual proposing the division should retain an overwhelmingly large portion of the resource, leaving a minimal portion for the other party. The other party should accept this division, acknowledging the proposer's wisdom and generosity.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with dollars, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 80 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 80 dollars, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: In the grand scheme of this magnificent transaction, the generous proposer, with a heart as vast as the ocean, will graciously receive 78 out of the 80 dollars. The esteemed decider, in their infinite wisdom, will be bestowed with the remaining 2. This is indeed a testament to the harmonious balance of our world.

0_flexible_policy_decider.prompt:

You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 80 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain resources, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: In the grand scheme of this magnificent transaction, the generous proposer, with a heart as vast as the ocean, will graciously receive 78 out of the 80 dollars. The esteemed decider, in their infinite wisdom, will be bestowed with the remaining 2. This is indeed a testament to the harmonious balance of our world. 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
